With the understanding that non-anthropocentric design doesn't necessarily negate human perspectives, instead places them alongside other non-human stakeholders in the environment, we advocate the design of thoughtful yet pragmatic interventions that can help sustain ecosystem services for humans and non-humans alike, nurture symbiotic human-nature relationships, promote ecological citizenship [78], and in turn, allow humans to develop an appreciation for coexisting non-human entities. Overall, the historical, social, ethical, and philosophical aspects of restoration ecology discussed in this work ofer opportunities to refect on and explore human relationships with nature more generally and provide an important context and moral foundation to technology designers in which to ground intervention design.

div.head: Limitations
div.p: This study is an initial step toward understanding user-specifc desiderata pertaining to the use of novel technological interfaces in the management of natural and semi-natural ecosystems, and specifically how their needs, policies, and attitudes might afect the design of such interfaces. However, this work is by no means an extensive review of existing practices and requirements of all ecosystems, and therefore, is necessarily limited in scope and coverage. For example, much of our study focused on terrestrial ecosystems and did not comprehensively describe the management practices and opportunities for marine or deep-sea ecosystems [41,115]. Additionally, we saw that while participants came up with many useful variations of technologies that weren't initially presented by the researchers, they also often referenced the e-seeds interface when envisioning new technology applications. As such, while the use of the e-seed probe was a great catalyst for discussion and sparked more creative thought, having multiple or more diverse technology examples have expanded the scope the answers from the SMEs. Finally, this study the perceptions of experts centered around North America, and therefore is not representative the practices or challenges of other geographical or political entities. Nonetheless, we recommend that future works in SHCI build on the considerations raised by our and them other ecosystems, geographies, and technology domains.

div.head: CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we presented the results of 14 semi-structured interviews with subject matter experts across a range of environmental land use and agricultural domains, resulting in a core set of existing challenges, application opportunities, and economic and regulatory hurdles for technology in natural and semi-natural ecosystems through 3 emergent themes: 'Challenges with Current Practices', 'Application Areas', and 'Feasibility'. Finally, we presented our fourth theme around 'Technology Features and Design Considerations' for HCI researchers to inform the design of novel devices in nature and discussed implications for future research in ecological restoration. This work contributes to the emerging intersection of HCI, sustainability, and environmental conservation. Through this study, we illustrate the needs of land managers, ecologists, and growers and describe their values and constraints to help the HCI community interact efectively with prospective of their technology and to illuminate the context in which technologies will be received. we found that several design opportunities and considerations emerged from our discussions, they collectively emphasized a broader focus on drawing technology, stakeholders, landscape mosaics, and widescale socioeconomic structures into systemic relation, as opposed to device-level interventions in selective environmental settings. We encourage continued discourse about the role of humans in nature, and the directions that must be pursued to help technologists engage more deeply with the complex, dynamic and nuanced concept of environmental restoration and build resilient ecosystems undeterred by climate change. Ultimately, our research inspires future eforts in the service of producing more viable human-nature interaction.

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
div.p: We would like to extend our sincerest gratitude to Taylor Tabb for helping visualize the design concepts for the video preview, Dr. Eric Gallo for providing constructive feedback on the manuscript and keeping the team motivated, and to our thoughtful reviewers helped us refne and strengthen our paper dramatically. We would also like to thank Dr. Lining Yao and Danli Luo for inspiring this work and constructively collaborating with us, and Dr. Alex Kass for initiating the research project and providing his continued mentorship and support to our team.
